text: space shuttle Atlantis to assemble the
framework for the science laboratories
of tomorrow
the sts-117 mission was a critical one
in the assembly sequence of the
International Space Station so 117 had a
huge piece of the truss which had a
solar array contained within it and the
job of the 117 mission was to bring that
piece of truss up attach it with the
robotic arm on the starboard side and
then eventually we would unfold a new
solar array to help us generate
electricity onboard the station this
would be my first spacewalk I was a
rookie on 117 but doing a spacewalk for
all practical purposes is similar to
doing a reverse scuba dive you go from a
very high pressure which is inside the
restaurant compartment 14.7 PSI to the
vacuum of space which is there a lot of
connections that need to be fastened a
lot of procedural steps that had to be
followed in sequence it involved a
pretty significant effort to figure out
the logistics of how do you assemble
this thing appropriately so that you
don't leave your crew without a
habitable module without power without
thermal protection and ultimately it
really was an a giant jigsaw puzzle and
you unfold a solar array and it's
connected with all its electrical lines
and then it sees Sun for the first time
it's going to generate electricity
well the surge of current through that
generated electricity was apparently
more than one of the Russian electronic
boxes could handle so as the current
surged through that box it fried that
box a problem was experienced by the
Russian computer
not just one but three of the command
and control computers you always ask
yourself when something goes wrong what
changed what did we do and the most
obvious thing that we came up with was a
you know why we just brought up a big
electrical component and we attached it
to the space station you know is it
possible that that action is what caused
this other thing to occur is it possible
that there may have been some sort of
static electricity that that when we
attached it to the space station that
maybe was AB something and consequently
that man power down we had to shut
computers off left and right had to shut
electrical systems off left and right
science instrumentation that was not
necessary
it went from being a bright research
laboratory to kind of this really eerie
a lot of dark shadows and just kind of
an eerie ship at that point you could
tell that there was a notable change in
the environment of the space station I
think there was a sensation that most
people had you know dull headaches you
could tell that the co2 levels were
rising although we were saying below any
any critical levels it just made for a
rather uncomfortable working situation
that you just had to power through
